supporting_text: The NAP mentions a National One Health Strategy which identifies AMR as a priority.
Objective 3.2: Decrease Hospital Acquired Infection (HAI) and associated AMR through facility based HAI surveillance programme (Human Health).
The NAP includes actions related to animal health, such as the establishment of a National Drug Regulatory Authority (NDRA) for veterinary sector.
The NAP mentions the need for environmental surveillance for AMR as part of the overall strategy.
The NAP includes objectives related to optimizing antimicrobial use in agriculture and food production sectors.
The NACC will report implementation status to NMSC, national agencies and international partners.
By 2022, the country would have carried out nationwide evidence-based awareness campaigns with regular Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E).
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
Detailed planning along with the budget allotted for the respective activities will be done in due course by national stakeholders.
The document does not contain an assessment of future budget requirements.
The NAP establishes a National Multi-Sectoral Steering Committee (NMSC) for Antimicrobial Resistance.
The NAP includes the establishment of a National Drug Policy with special reference to AMAs and AMR.
The NAP aims to revise curricula in undergraduate medical and veterinary, food industry and agriculture teaching.
The NAP includes plans for nationwide evidence-based awareness campaigns targeting various audiences.
The NAP mentions collaboration with WHO, FAO, and OIE for technical support and implementation.
The NAP includes the establishment of a national AMR surveillance system and coordination structure.
The NAP aims to develop a One Health AMR surveillance plan in humans, animals, and food.
The NAP includes objectives related to hygiene, infection prevention, and control measures.
The NAP mentions the need to develop guidelines for AMR surveillance incorporating international standards.
The NAP includes the development of an essential medicines list with special reference to the use of antimicrobial agents.
The NAP includes the establishment of a regulatory framework for control of human and veterinary use of antimicrobial substances.
The NAP envisions collaborations with national and international agencies for implementation of strategic research agenda.
